title:
All-Optical Azimuthal Trapping of Dissipative Kerr Multi-Solitons for
  Relative Noise Suppression
authors:
Pradyoth Shandilya, Shao-Chien Ou, Jordan Stone, Curtis Menyuk, Miro
  Erkintalo, Kartik Srinivasan and Gregory Moille
abstract:
Temporal cavity solitons, or dissipative Kerr solitons (DKS) in integrated
microresonators, are essential for deployable metrology technologies. Such
applications favor the lowest noise state, typically the single-DKS state where
one soliton is in the resonator. Other multi-DKS states can also be reached,
offering better conversion efficiency and thermal stability, potentially
simplifying DKS-based technologies. Yet they exhibit more noise due to relative
soliton jitter, and are usually not compatible with targeted applications. We
demonstrate that Kerr-induced synchronization, an all-optical trapping
technique, can azimuthally pin the multi-DKS state to a common reference field.
This method ensures repetition rate noise independent of the number of
solitons, making a multi-DKS state indistinguishable from a single-DKS state in
that regard, akin to trapped-soliton molecule behavior. Supported by
theoretical analysis and experimental demonstration in an integrated
microresonator, this approach provides metrological capacity regardless of the
number of cavity solitons, benefiting numerous DKS-based metrology
applications.
